support_summary: ATXN3 directly interacts with p62 (SQSTM1), an autophagic receptor protein involved in the formation of aggresomes.

functions.cellular_process: The autophagy receptor protein p62/SQSTM1 directly interacts with the pathogenic, polyglutamine (polyQ) expanded form of ATXN3. This interaction is a key step in recognizing and sequestering misfolded, aggregation-prone ATXN3.
functions.effect_description: By binding to polyQ-expanded ATXN3, SQSTM1 facilitates the transport of these protein aggregates along microtubules to the microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), promoting the formation of a large inclusion body known as an aggresome. This process sequesters the toxic protein species, which is a protective cellular response.
biological_consequence: Pathogenic polyQ-expanded ATXN3 accumulates in the cell -> SQSTM1 directly binds to polyQ-expanded ATXN3 -> The ATXN3-SQSTM1 complex is transported towards the MTOC -> Aggregates coalesce into a single large aggresome -> Cellular toxicity from soluble misfolded ATXN3 is reduced.
specific_effects: SQSTM1 promotes the aggresome formation of pathogenic ataxin-3.
The interaction is specific to the polyQ-expanded form of ataxin-3.
Overexpression of SQSTM1 enhances aggresome formation, while its knockdown inhibits it.
This SQSTM1-mediated process protects cells against pathogenic ataxin-3-induced cell death.

evidence.paper_title: p62/Sequestosome 1 Regulates Aggresome Formation of Pathogenic Ataxin-3 with Expanded Polyglutamine
evidence.relevant_quote: In this study we demonstrate that p62 directly interacts with pathogenic Machado Joseph Disease (MJD)-associated protein ataxin-3 with polyglutamine (polyQ) expansion. Moreover, p62 could regulate the aggresome formation of pathogenic ataxin-3 and protect cells against pathogenic ataxin-3-induced cell death.

summary: ATXN3 activates SQSTM1 to modulate aggresome formation of mutant atxn3.
